choices: Oh, the woman's insane. Keep moving.
Did you say ale? Sure, why not?
1.content:
Farewell, mother. I take my leave.

William left his little thatch-roofed home and mounted his steed. Small though it was, the coal-black beast was swift as any other as it took off at a run. William was headed northward to Camelot, the beautiful court of King Arthur and the legendary Knights of the Round Table. For the past five years, William had dreamed of becoming one of Arthur's knights. He had heard of their exploits--the wondrous tales of Lancelot and Galahad and Gawain--and now, the King had returned from a long and arduous quest. William's time had finally come.

He came to a bridge which passed over a dark lake. In the distance, William could hear the eerie voice of a fairy or other mythical creature singing a lament. He paid the voice no attention and continued onwards to Camelot.

He arrived at a village and in the distance, he could see a great stone castle--Camelot, at last! He moved onwards through the village, but was stopped by an old hag.

Evening, deary! Fancy a drink? My brother runs a pub in town, and I think he'd be more than willing to treat a young man so fine as yourself to a pint or two of ale.

Well...
1.title: Prologue: The Journey to Camelot

11.content:
I'm afraid not. You see, I journey to Camelot to meet with King Arthur and I cannot stop now.

I see. Well then...

A strange look came into the woman's eyes as she pulled a dagger out from her dress.

Spare change for a poor old woman?

William drew his sword and was faced with a choice.
11.title: Oh, the woman's insane. Keep moving.

111.content:
William sheathed his sword and pulled out his purse. From it he took one shilling and handed it to the hag.

Sure you can't spare another shilling or two?

Take what I've given you and be thankful for it.

William continued onward, but the hag picked up a large jagged stone and hurled it at his head. He quickly fell off his mount, and the woman seized him and stabbed him to death. She stole all his money and valuables and ran away.

Must you be so kind to a beggar? They've no honor. Anyway, the adventure ends here.
111.title: Here you go...

choices: What a moron! Go on in.
112.content:
William decapitated the hag with his blade and quickly fled before anyone took notice. Onward he rode towards Camelot, and finally he arrived at the gates. Above him loomed the massive castle that housed King Arthur's court. Before him stood a gallant knight.

Good day, he said, What is your purpose here?

I wish to join King Arthur's knights at the Round Table, sir.

He's, uh, he's very busy at the moment.

No he's not.

Yes he is. He said it himself. No visitors; I'm very busy.

He was only jesting.

Oh, I see how it is. You think that just because I'm keeping watch at the gate, I'm not qualified to sit at the Round Table. Is that it? I bet you think me pretty dim-witted, do you not? I'll have you know I'm much smarter than Lancelot. He never even went to college.

And you did?

For Christ's sake, yes! Of course I went to college. Community, but still...

I bet it gets old, watching this stupid gate. Am I right?

Terribly.

And for one so qualified as yourself, it must be positively torturous.

Yes indeed.

Tell you what. I'll keep watch. You go into town. Go to headquarters and file a complaint.

Huh. I wasn't aware we had a headquarters.

Of course we have! Go on, they'll help reassign you.

All right. Thanks!

With that, the knight left for the village.
112.title: Do what must be done.

1121.content:
For about an hour, William stood faithfully at the castle gates as he relieved the knight of his duties. Suddenly, the knight returned with his sword firmly in hand. He pierced William through the chest.

Real funny, mutha-fucka.

Eh, at least the world's a little less brainless now.
1121.title: Keep watch until he returns.

1122.content:
William laughed at his own cleverness as he continued on into the castle. After passing through a few chambers, he stood in the great hall of Camelot. Before him lay the Round Table, and at its head sat King Arthur.

Oh, for Christ's sake... I thought I told that fool not to admit anyone!

William bowed before the King as he said:

My lord, I am William. I have journeyed far to your marvelous court in hopes of joining you and your knights at the Round Table.

My dear boy, currently, I am not hiring. Kindly get the hell out.

But your majesty, it is my dream to serve you.

Son, no one wants to serve me anymore, not after what happened this past year. Deadly rabbits, bridges of death... It was horrible.

My lord, I will remain faithful. I know well what dangers await.

At this, Sir Lancelot burst into the hall.

Sir, the people are starting to gripe again.

Damn it, Lancelot. If this is about that bloody dragon again...

It is, my lord. Would you like me to take care of it?

No, I've a better idea. This young man here... Jonathan, was it?

William.

Whatever. Anyway, son, if you wish to prove yourself worthy of my knights, go slay that dragon. It's in a cave somewhere, I don't know where.

Um... Sure thing, your majesty.

Go then, and may God be with you.

William left the hall and mounted his steed. Taking one last look at the castle, he sped off into the night.

Damn it, Lancelot. Fix me an ale.
1122.title: What a moron! Go on in.

11221.content:
William bravely sallied forth to slay the dragon, but to his chagrin, he had no idea where to look. Then oddly, he saw a sign on the same road he came in on, that he could swear hadn't been their before. And next to it was the Knight that had guarded the gate, with an evil grin on his face.

William said, "King Arthur has sent me on a noble quest to slay the dragon!

The Knight tried to restrain a chuckle and said, "Ah I expected he would.... just follow the signs."

The sign led William off of the main road and along a trail, and soon there was another sign, "To the Dragon... you're almost there!" He shortly came to a cave with a large dragon sized opening where there was a huge sign with an arrow, stating "This is it.... the dragon is in here!".

Someething about all of the signs seemed odd to William, they wording was overly large, and crude and seemed like they might have been made by some half-inteligent animal instead of a human. But he dismissed that notion, and called into the mouth of the cave, "Vile dragon, come out in the open for I intend to slay thee!"

A large reptilian head poked from the cave, that terrified William's horse, which bucked and threw him to the ground. William quickly recovered, drew his sword and swung with all his might just as a large taloned paw descended on him. The blade clattered uselessly on the dragon's hard scales, and with a quick shake, the dragon had knocked it out of William's hand. Then the beast leaned back against the hill next to the cave's mouth, and while he hummed a tune, began pealing off William's armor and then his clothing. Then it opened its terible jaws widely and was about to pop William inside when the exasperated knight screamed, " Wait, this isn't supposed to happen! "

The dragon paused, and said , to the trembling William, "Well of course it it my boy, its part of the deal."

"What deal?", William said, relieved that the dragon could talk, seemed quite civil, and had not swallowed him already.

Why the deal with King Arthur, Arthur PENDRAGON, to be precise. You see, to carry the title Pendragon, you make a deal with a dragon to be the kingdom's protector, and to show other kings and enemies he has a dragon protector, he displays the image of the dragon on his flags and pennants, hence the name PENDRAGON.... now what part about this don't you understand?

William stammered nervously, "Well, The part about King Arthur sending me out to slay you?".

"Slay me?" the dragon chortled in derision. Humans don't really slay dragons, just look at the success you had, though I suppose there are some chidren's fairytales that say otherwise, and good thing for them because they keep fools like you coming. You see, part of the deal with me being protector dragon of the kingdom is that I get three, free square meals a day, and I am afraid he sent you instead instead of a fat calf for tonight's supper. I can scarely blame him, as a calf runs upwards to eight schillings and six pence these days, while I should expect you didn't cost him anything, I suspect Now while its tur that a fat calf would be a bit more filling, there is my second business you know, which makes you nearly as good as the calf."

"W-what's that?", Wiliam mumbled in fear.

The dragon nodded his toothy muzzle towards the pile of William's armor on the ground, and said, "Why, didn't you know? I happen to be the greatest purveyor of used armor in all of Camelot!" And on that note he swallowed William in a sinle gulp.
11221.title: Onward!

12.content:
William dismounted outside the pub, and the hag asked him to follow her to the back entrance.

Why?

Well, you see lad, if you go through the front, you'll look like a customer! Other customers might get jealous. It's not every day you get a pint on the house.

Ah, I see...

William followed her around to the back, but quickly noticed there was no entrance. Before he could say anything, the hag pulled out a dagger and slit William's throat.

Sorry, lad. Money is money, after all.

She stole William's purse and other valuables, and left his corpse out behind the pub. Hours later, his body, mutilated by hounds and birds, was discovered by the pub's owner.

Not the best way to start an adventure. Next time, think before trusting a hag.
12.title: Sounds Good To Me

info.brief_description: William, a brave and blockheaded knight is hell-bent on joining Arthur's court at Camelot.
info.description: 934 A.D. - Arthur, King of the Britons, has just returned home from an epic, ill-fated quest to find the Holy Grail. He faced a great many foes and lost many brave men (and some minstrels), and in the end, all was for naught. So, he, along with Sir Bedivere and Sir Lancelot, embarked on a long journey back home to his beautiful court at Camelot. Pleased though he was to find that his beloved Camelot was no longer a silly place, his happiness was short-lived. For a new prospective knight had emerged, a young lad named William, and Arthur had not the energy to partake in the painstaking process of testing the boy. Instead, Arthur devised a simple, cruel method of challenging his competence...
info.pretty_title: The Tale of William and the Dragon
